subject: Re: keyboard/lexical set proposal
msgSnippet: Please note that any mapping will satisfy your first point (ie: font deveolopers can work with any mapping.  You correctly point this out in the sentence above
messageBody:
Please note that any mapping will satisfy your first point (ie: font
deveolopers can work with any mapping. You correctly point this out
in the sentence above where you say that that any internal
representation doesn't really matter).
Also note that if you want to read directly QS text with english
fonts in email then there are many mappings better than sampa for
this (eg: the mapping I mentioned in a previous email that uses many
null characters).
To avoid ambiguity you don't need to have a one-to-one, but rather
you can not have a one-to-many mapping. A many-to-one mapping is
fine to use. The result of a many-to-one mapping is unique and
totally unambiguous by definition. (I suspect that it is impossible
to code a one-to-many mapping anyway). Software that handles text
doesn't care at all how the text is mapped cause it just manipulates
the letter codes the same way for each font.

The only benefit that sampa does offer is that it is based on a
linguistic standard and as such it helps people who are already
familiar with the standard. But as has already been pointed out by
other group members this benefits only a very, very small precentage
of the general population. The fact that it doesn't use everyday
common keys/sound combinations (such as y for 'ye') actually
disadvantages most people.

As far as the general population is concerned a good mapping is one
that is easy to learn/remember and quick and comfortable to type. I
personally want a mapping like this, but I would also like it to
fulfil my need for text that is quite readable by the everyday
readers when viewed using english fonts.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
<freeman@...> wrote:
>
.....
>
> Now, the internal representation that you choose to use in the
> dictionary doesn't really matter. In the end you're going to
display
> QS, so any notation will do. The QS-SAMPA proposal has a different
> purpose. It aims to provide a single standard for two things: (1) a
> keyboard layout that font developers can follow, and (2) a plain-
text
> format that allows the easy exchange of QS text in email and other
> software applications.
>
> For these purposes, we need a one-to-one correspondence between the
> letters of the Read Alphabet and the ASCII notation we use to
> represent them. Otherwise, something typed in plain text will be
> ambiguous without another layer of information.
>


peter
